column1: The Tulip in the Swan@https://apod.nasa.gov/apod/image/1909/Tulip_CropRobertEder1024.jpg@2019-09-21@Robert Eder@https://apod.nasa.gov/apod/image/1909/Tulip_CropRobertEder.jpg@Framing a bright emission region
column2: this telescopic view looks out across a pretty field of stars along the plane of our Milky Way Galaxy
column3: toward the nebula rich constellation Cygnus the Swan. Popularly called the Tulip Nebula
column4: the reddish glowing cloud of interstellar gas and dust is also found in the 1959 catalog by astronomer Stewart Sharpless as Sh2-101. About 8
column5: 000 light-years distant and 70 light-years across the complex and beautiful nebula blossoms near the center of this composite image. Ultraviolet radiation from young energetic O stars at the edge of the Cygnus OB3 association
column6: ionizes the atoms and powers the emission from the Tulip Nebula.@image@v1

column4: by noting the absorption of water-vapor colors when the planet moved in front of the star.  The featured illustration imagines exoplanet K2-18b on the right
column5: its parent red dwarf star K2-18 on the left
column6: and an unconfirmed sister planet between them.@image@v1
